verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Introduction to the Nazirite vow laws; continues the pattern of divine instruction through Moses.

verses.text: "Speak to the Israelites and say to them: When a man or woman makes a special vow, the vow of a Nazirite, to dedicate himself to the LORD,
verses.comment: Note: Both men and women can become Nazirites; reflects the original Hebrew.

verses.text: he must abstain from wine and other alcoholic drink; he must not drink vinegar made from wine or other strong drink. He must not drink any grape juice or eat grapes, whether fresh or dried.
verses.comment: Focuses on abstaining from all grape products, as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: During the entire period of his Nazirite vow, he must not eat anything that comes from the grapevine, not even the seeds or the skins.
verses.comment: Explicit mention of seeds and skins preserves the strictness of the original prohibition.

verses.text: Throughout the days of his Nazirite vow, no razor shall come upon his head; until the time is completed when he is separated to the LORD, he shall be holy. He must let the hair of his head grow long.
verses.comment: Thematic links to Samson; maintaining hair as a symbol of separation.

verses.text: Throughout the time he is dedicated to the LORD, he must not go near a dead body.
verses.comment: Echoes priestly restrictions regarding exposure to the dead.

verses.text: He must not make himself unclean, even for his father, mother, brother, or sister, when they die, because his dedication to God is on his head.
verses.comment: Similar in form to the priests' restrictions; the Nazirite's dedication supplied as reason.

verses.text: All the days of his vow of separation, he is holy to the LORD.
verses.comment: Restates the Nazirites' holy status during their vow.

verses.text: If someone dies very suddenly beside him and makes his Nazirite hair unclean, he must shave his head on the day he becomes clean; he shall shave it on the seventh day.
verses.comment: Describes the process for accidental defilement by proximity to death.

verses.text: On the eighth day, he shall bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons to the priest at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
verses.comment: Sacrificial offering for purification; parallels other cleansing rites.

verses.text: The priest shall offer one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering, and make atonement for him, since he sinned by being near a dead body. That same day, he shall consecrate his head again.
verses.comment: Explains the necessity of re-consecration after accidental defilement.

verses.text: He must rededicate the days of his Nazirite vow and bring a year-old male lamb as a guilt offering. The previous days do not count, because his separation was defiled.
verses.comment: The time of the vow resets after defilement; only future days count.

verses.text: Now this is the law for the Nazirite: When the days of his vow are completed, he shall be brought to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
verses.comment: The conclusion of the Nazirite period; prepares for offerings.

verses.text: There he must present his offering to the LORD: a year-old male lamb without defect as a burnt offering, a year-old female lamb without defect as a sin offering, a ram without defect as a peace offering,
verses.comment: Brings all three types of sacrifices: burnt, sin, and peace.

verses.text: along with a basket of unleavened bread—cakes made with fine flour mixed with oil and unleavened wafers spread with oil—and their grain and drink offerings.
verses.comment: Details unleavened bread as part of the Nazirite offering.

verses.text: The priest shall present them before the LORD and offer both the sin offering and the burnt offering.
verses.comment: Summary of the priest's duties with the Nazirite offerings.

verses.text: He shall also offer the ram as a peace offering to the LORD, together with the basket of unleavened bread. The priest shall present its grain and drink offerings.
verses.comment: Order of offerings is specified, matching Levitical procedures.

verses.text: The Nazirite shall then shave the hair of his vow at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, and take the hair that was shaved off and put it on the fire under the peace offering sacrifice.
verses.comment: The shaving of hair as a ritual act; hair burnt with the sacrifice.

verses.text: The priest shall take the boiled shoulder of the ram, and one unleavened cake from the basket, and one unleavened wafer, and put them into the hands of the Nazirite after he has shaved his vow hair.
verses.comment: Specific detail of which parts of the sacrifice are given to the Nazirite.

verses.text: The priest shall wave them as a wave offering before the LORD. This, together with the wave offering and the portion given to the priest, belongs to him. Afterward, the Nazirite may drink wine.
verses.comment: Wave offering marks the end of Nazirite restrictions; can now drink wine.

verses.text: This is the law of the Nazirite who makes a vow, and of his offering to the LORD for his separation, in addition to whatever else he can afford. He must do in accordance with the vow he has taken, as the law of his separation requires.
verses.comment: Allows for extra offerings beyond the required ones, according to the Nazirite's means.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: New section begins, introducing the priestly blessing. No significant difference.

verses.text: "Speak to Aaron and his sons, saying: This is how you shall bless the Israelites. Say to them:
verses.comment: God's instructions for priestly blessing. No significant difference.

verses.text: "The LORD bless you and keep you;
verses.comment: Maintained word-for-word as in Hebrew blessing.

verses.text: the LORD make his face shine upon you and be gracious to you;
verses.comment: Maintained, with 'shine upon you' as literal translation.

verses.text: the LORD lift up his face toward you and give you peace."
verses.comment: 'Lift up his face' translated literally, preserving original wording.

verses.text: "So they will put my name upon the Israelites, and I will bless them."
verses.comment: Closes the blessing section; 'put my name' reflects the Hebrew idiom.
